Okay, does that take any of the heat off your new distribution facility because you're not going be doing tobacco there?

---

【回答: Kenneth Martindale (Executives)】
Not really. I mean, tobacco's a fairly easy category to handle. But it simplifies things a little bit because we don't have to worry about stamps and the cigarettes and everything. So it really doesn't -- it doesn't really apply to that DC. It was really more of an overall network opportunity for us to leverage them and give them a little more volume.

---

【質問: Mark Wiltamuth (Analysts)】
And for you, is it more of a "cost of goods sold" savings? Or are you doing better on in-stock?

---

【回答: Kenneth Martindale (Executives)】
It helps our distribution cost substantially, and it should help our in-stocks. But it's more really helping us on the supply chain side, honestly.

---

【回答: Matt Schroeder (Executives)】
Want to thank everybody for calling in today. Appreciate your time and have a good day.

3208986.eventHeadline: Next Plc, H1 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 10, 2015
3208986.transcript_text1:
Good. Let's start. Well, good morning, everyone. Welcome to the Super Thursday announcement from NEXT of our half year results. I'd like -- you've probably noticed there's a different face up here this morning, and I would just like to welcome Amanda and say how delighted I am that she has joined us up here.

---

Thank you.

---

Good morning. Well, I think we had a good 6 months. Our sales were up 3.5%, which was slightly higher than the range that we gave you earlier this year. Profit's up 7% and earnings per share up by 8%. During this year, we've done no share buybacks, but we have, up to date, returned GBP 400 million to shareholders through dividends and special dividends.
You'll have noticed in the notes that have gone out, that we expect Directory debt to go up by GBP 200 million this year. We have to finance that, and the board have agreed that we will do that out of our existing debt facilities, and it won't affect return of cash to shareholders. So we will return all of our surplus cash to shareholders in the form of either share buybacks or special dividends for the remainder of this year.
Looking forward, we expect sales to be a little bit stronger against last year in the second half, but we've left our estimated profit and the same guidance as we gave in July, which is GBP 805 million to GBP 845 million, so that hasn't changed. The rest will come from Simon.

---

You've given half the presentation already. Good morning, everybody. So as the Chairman said, actually, sales up 2.7%, but full price sales up 3.5%. Not our most sparkling season, but about 2% better than we were expecting on full price. And the reason we were so conservative, to put that in context, that's 16% up on 2 years ago. So this time last year, we had a very good first half. Operating profit up 6.7%. Main driver there is bought-in gross margin, and the difference between full price sales and operating profit is bought-in gross margin.
Profit before tax. Interest charges flat on last year. Outstanding debt around about the same as last year. Looking forward to the full year, we're expecting debt to rise for the full year, but interest charges, last year GBP 30 million; year ahead, we're expecting around GBP 31 million. Interest charges won't go up necessarily by as much as you'd expect because last year, we had a lot of cash on deposit earning very little interest. So the cost of depleting that cash is low. Taxation charge of 20.2% is in line with the national rate for corporations.
Earnings per share up 8%. This is boosted by buybacks at the beginning of last year. Ordinary dividend up 6% at the half, and we would expect that to be 1/3 of the total dividend -- ordinary dividend paid this year, and the 6% is in line with our forecast for growth and earnings per share for the full year.
Moving on to cash flow. First thing to say is the GBP 70 million outflow in operational cash. This is cash flow before any distribution to shareholders. 2 things are going on here: increased CapEx and increased flow of cash into Directory debt.
In terms of capital expenditure, up in the first half and expected to be up for the full year. And looking forward to the full year, we expect a GBP 45 million increase in CapEx, GBP 20 million of that coming from increased expenditure on new openings. Of that -- sorry, on stores. Of that, GBP 10 million of that increase is an increase in cosmetic refits. So last year, we spent GBP 6 million, which was unusually low amount for us to spend on cosmetics throughout maintenance CapEx; this year, around GBP 15 million. We would expect that number to average around GBP 11 million for the next 2 or 3 years.
Systems, an increase of GBP 7 million here. Of that increase, GBP 6 million of it relates to the purchase of new tills required to operate our new till system. And just to be clear, on systems CapEx, we only capitalize hardware. So this is the cost of writing the software, which we've done ourselves, is written off against revenues. That GBP 6 million is a hardware cost rather than software cost.
And head office, we continue the process of making our head office fit for purpose this year. We're building a photo studio on-site, which will -- makes much more efficient at photographing our samples. We will extend and refurbish our children's wear department, refurbish our product and finance departments, and we will -- we have now completed a new systems building. I would expect that head office infrastructure figure to drop dramatically next year, certainly to be less than GBP 10 million.
Warehouse, GBP 27 million. The increase of GBP 15 million here is more than all accounted for by the GBP 20 million that we're spending on the new furniture warehouse. That warehouse won't be complete till next year. We expect further GBP 15 million of CapEx on that project in the first half of next year. It should be up and running sort of middle of next year.
In terms of working capital, big outflow here, around GBP 70 million. There's GBP 135 million outflow into Directory debt, and that's been offset by less outflow into stock and some property stock that has bought cash back into the business.
In terms of distribution to shareholders, 2 special dividends last year, both for 50p. This year, 2 special dividends, one of 60p, one of 50p, so a slight increase in the amount of paid out in special dividends.
Share buybacks, GBP 105 million last year. That was the last -- the last set of buybacks that we did and that hasn't occurred this year. So we had -- in summary, had GBP 70 million less inflow from operations and GBP 100 million less outflow from shareholder distributions roughly, GBP 90 million less outflow.
In terms of the balance sheet. Stock up 5.5%. This is pretty much in line with our forecast for sales in the second half. The midpoint of our sales guidance for the second half is 5.5%. Debtors, this is where there's a significant increase, 18.6% increase. And this is being driven by this  GBP 135 million increase in Directory debt, which is up 21% on last year. That wasn't expected. It's not being driven by credit sales. Credit sales were only up 2%. This is all being driven by the fact that our customers are paying down their balances slower as a result of us changing our minimum payment rules.
You'll be pleased to hear that I'm going to talk about that in great length later, so you've got something to look forward to as I plow through the numbers.
Net debt at the half year, GBP 20 million down. Looking forward to net debt for the full year. We started the year with GBP 515 million of debt. We expect to generate through operations GBP 386 million of surplus cash. That's cash after paying interest, dividends and ordinary dividends and CapEx. We plan to distribute that through 4 special dividends, 3 of which have been paid, 1 of which has been announced. So a GBP 341 million outflow into special dividends, and on top of that, a further outflow of GBP 200 million into Directory debt. And, obviously, there's a question here as to whether the outflow into Directory debt should be funded through our balance sheet or funded through reducing the amount of special dividends we pay going forward. We've decided to fund it through our balance sheet as the Chairman -- as Chairman mentioned.
Just to explain our logic here, year-end debt of GBP 670 million. First and foremost, that debt, we believe, is comfortably within the investment-grade levels that we have set as our objective for the company. I know that there are people -- Andrew Jones, our Treasurer, was very worried about me saying this because he thought that the credit rating people in the room would be offended that we were usurping there. I said, this is a very rough -- a rough estimate of what the amount is. What you can see is that there's clearly a long way off our year-end levels. So first of all, investment-grade. Secondly, our financing is very secure. Our peak financing requirements for the year around GBP 900 million. That's covered by GBP 788 million of bonds and a further GBP 550 million of bank facilities. So we've got headroom of over GBP 400 million from our peak borrowing requirements, which last about 1 week.
So we think the financing is very secure. And what you'll see from this is that the financing is secure even if we lose the -- even if we don't renew, or replace rather, the 2016 bond, which it is our intention to do, but we don't need to do that.
The final thing is the Directory debt is a high-yield secured asset that covers the cost of its own financing 3x to 5x. So for all those reasons, we think the right thing to do is fund it through the balance sheet. And actually, about 75% of it is funded through the balance sheet.
Moving on to retail. That's the picture of our new shop in High Wycombe, which we hope -- which is forecast to take around GBP 15 million, but assessed [ph] at around GBP 30 [ph] million.
Retail sales up 0.2%, full price sales up 0.8%. In terms of where that growth has come from, 2.2% growth from new space, so same-store sales down on last year as we expected. The net space increase is 3.6%, which means that the yield on the additional space is around 61%. We would expect that this number to hover around 60%. You'll remember last year, it was exceptionally high at around 80%. That's a more normal return.
New store performance. In terms of the financial performance of the new stores that we've opened over the last 12 months, new stores are still doing really well for us, 10% ahead of the targets we set them, payback of 18 months on the net capital invested and a net branch profitability, that's the profit of the store before central overheads, of 24%. So really healthy -- still very healthy growth in space.
In terms of looking at what will happen to our portfolio for the full year, we start the year at -- we started the year with 539 shops. We aim to open 22, of which 8 are re-sites of existing shops, extend 13 shops and close 19 shops, of which 11 are re-sites.
And the sharp ones amongst you will have instantly noticed that there appears to be a problem with the slide. In that, we're re-siting 8 shops into new, but closing 11. And the reason for that is that on 1 site, we're closing 2 shops to open 1 new one. Another site, we've closed the shop, but we will close the shop before the year-end, but open the new shop after the year-end. And the final one is because we are re-siting to an extension rather than a re-site. So just wanted to explain the anomaly before anyone picks up on it.
542 shops is what we intend -- to end the year, around 300,000 square feet of additional space, an increase of 4% on last year, 50,000 less than where we had hoped to be. That's because 2 stores have slipped from opening at the back end of this year into the front end of next year. We don't -- those -- the slippage of those 2 stores won't make any material difference to the numbers in either year.
In terms of retail profit, an increase in margin of 0.8%. All of that is about margin. Bought-in gross margin up 0.8%. We didn't intend our bought-in gross margin to be up 0.8%. We set our targets flat with last year. We had a very good buying rate and the buyers overachieved. So the buyer is not allowed to miss their margin target, but they are allowed to overachieve it and they did so with gusto. Obviously, that does put some pressure on the margins in the first half of next year, which you need to be mindful of, although we have set our spring-summer margins to be -- next year to be in line with last year -- in line with this year, rather. Does that makes sense?
Markdown, an improvement of 0.2%. We had less stock going into the sale. We actually didn't sell it through as well as the previous year. But the overall effect of that, combined with an exceptional stock price of last year, was a slight improvement on -- in markdown.
Achieved gross margin up 1%. We should say that for the autumn season, we don't expect any improvement in bought-in gross margin. And we have visibility of those numbers, so you should rely on that.
Store payroll, adverse movement to 0.2%. 2 things going on here. Pay rises, which I'll talk about later, cost us around -- pay rise and same-store sales decline cost us around 0.6%. Productivity measures and improvements reduced that by 0.4%.
Store occupancy, adverse movement to 0.1%. Same-store sales moving backwards increases rents and rates as a percentage of sales, but depreciation is declining as more stores are -- become fully depreciated. In addition -- in terms of actual rental inflation itself, we're not seeing any significant rental inflation in our store portfolio at the moment. And the vast majority of renewals are at 0 or at around 0 and reviews at around 0.
Warehouse and distribution, adverse movement of 0.2%. This is all about wages in the warehouse rising slightly faster than sales. Central overheads, positive movement. This is because we're expecting profits to be up less this year than last year, and therefore, things like incentives will be lower this year than last year.
Moving on to Directory. Increase of 8.2%, which is GBP 58 million increase. And I thought it would be useful, because of the structure of Directory is changing. We used to just break that out in terms of where that growth has come from.
NEXT U.K., there's a NEXT brand -- branded stock sold in the U.K., was up GBP 19 million. That was much better than we're expecting. We're actually expecting GBP 10 million for the full year, so we underestimated NEXT brand in the U.K., still only up 3.5% on last year.
LABEL, up 30% on last year, an increase of GBP 22 million. This is not as good as it looks. Full price sales were up more like 20%. So we'd slightly over-edged the LABEL target.
Total Directory U.K. up 6%, GBP 41 million and then on top of that, another GBP 17 million from overseas, growing at 24%.
Actually, I should've said LABEL margin, we predicted was going to be 15%. And despite the increase in markdown, because more of this stock went through wholesale rather than commission, we still expect our margin on LABEL sales to be around 15% for the full year. That's without interest, so just I should reiterate that.
In terms of overseas, overseas hit its sales target, but we are expecting some margin erosion. And we had hoped to achieve 18% profit, we'll actually choose 16.5% profit. The reason for that is that we've had some very big devaluations in Eastern Europe, Kazakhstan, Ukraine, Russia. And in those countries, we haven't passed on the full effect of the devaluation to the customer. Still making a profit in those countries, but not as big a profit as we were hoping. We sort of shared the pain with the consumer, so we're expecting 16.5% profit on our overseas business this year.
In terms of total sales, GBP 58 million, 8.2%. That 8.2% has come from growth in our customer base of 13%, of which 7% is growth in U.K. customers, 65% growth in overseas customers. Obviously, the overseas customers growing far faster than the base because the newest customers spend the least.
The 7% though, although on the surface of things, that looks very healthy, 6. -- 6% growth from 7% customers. Underneath there is a structural change in terms of what's happening with our credit and cash customers, and I'm going to cover that in much more detail later.
Operating profit up 7%, so margin erosion in Directory. Bought-in gross margin up 0.5%, not the 0.8% experienced in retail. On NEXT stock, the bought-in gross margin did increase by 0.8%. However, because Directory has LABEL stock and overseas stock that is at lower bought-in gross margins, that has suppressed the growth in bought-in gross margin in Directory.
Markdown, an adverse movement to 0.5%. We kept pretty much all of the sales stock the Directory generated, we kept in Directory. Normally, we transfer some to retail. But as the Directory sale has become more efficient at clearing stock, so the business has kept more of its stock. So stock for sale was up 22%, sales were only up -- sales weren't up at all, they were flat, which causes adverse movement of 0.5%. That is slightly misleading because the timing of the sale meant that a lot of the sale dispatches this year happened in the second half rather than the first half and that was the difference in timing.
If you take the sale over the first few weeks, sale over the first 4 weeks, you'll find that the sale -- sales to date on sales stock are up 18%. So we will recover some of that margin in the second half, about 0.3% it. Around GBP 2 million worth of that loss in the first half will come back in the second half.
So achieved gross margin flat. Interest income, adverse movement to 0.2%. This is because credit sales and interest income are growing slower than sales. Bad debt continue -- we continue to see -- so much of a surprise, we continue to see an improvement in bad debt. Marketing costs, an improvement to 0.4%. Part of this is about a provision we took last year, then didn't use and released this year, that's about 0.2% of that. The balance is saving on publications. I'm sorry, not publications, it's a saving on some unproductive marketing we did last year. I apologize.
Warehouse and distribution, adverse movement to 0.9%. Of that 0.9%, 0.2% of it is a result of wage inflation in the warehouses. The balance, 0.7%, is because the participation of our overseas business is growing, and that has much higher warehouse and distribution costs. Central overheads, same comment as retail, so overall up 0.3% and no erosion in Directory margins.
Directory margins for the full year, we're expecting to be sort of flattish as we are expecting retail margins taking off to be flattish as well. But long term, what you can see from this is that the growth in our overseas business and the decline in the credit business will, long term, put structural pressure on the net margins of Directory. So that's something you should put into your longer-term plans, which I know are much longer than our own, because you have much more complex spreadsheets that are much more exciting.
So moving on to the focus part of the presentation. And you'll notice this presentation is mercifully -- feels mercifully quick today, because I know you've got far more important companies to rush off and cover later on. So we'll be a little bit briefer today. I'm going to start with Directory credit.
We've already talked about the 7% increase in total customer base. That is made up of 2 things: 40% increase in our cash customers. These are customers that come onto the site and pay immediately using debit and credit cards. That number, just -- these are a little bit of a health warning, because it's quite -- it's harder to tell with cash customers whether it's the same customer returning or not.
If they've moved and come back with a different email address, then it's much harder to trace them back to the same thing than if they had an account where they tend to -- it's more obvious that they're restarting. So cash customers, very good growth, and this is about us reaching a whole other people who 10, 15 years ago wouldn't even have considered themselves to be mail order shoppers at all. The downside of that is that our credit customer base is eroding. It's running at a rate around 0.3%. It's important to understand the nature of that decline. It's not that our credit customers are leaving us in larger numbers. So if you look at the attrition rates, this is the percentage of the customer base that closes their account each year.
What you can see is it actually has remained steady for the last 3 years and actually has declined in the current year. And we would expect -- as the base declines, we would expect the quality to improve, so that shouldn't come as a surprise. The thing that's holding the -- that's moving the credit business back is the number of new recruits. And what you see is a dramatic fall in number of new recruits into this year, and that's what's giving us our net fall. It's not quite as bad as it looks because credit sales are still growing, albeit margin. So the customers who remain with us are spending more on average.
So I don't think that, that credit sales increase running ahead of the declining base makes the problem any less. What it does do is probably delay the problem. It turns into sort of a less of an acute problem, more of a chronic problem for the Directory. The question is what can we do about it? We talked about this in the year-end results and 2 things: first is, 6 months ago, this is all we were doing to promote the account, pay on account or pay now. That was the only choice you got. We've done a whole lot of trials to promote the use of the account at point of order, both for first-time cash orders and when they come back to the site to reorder. We succeed -- that's had some moderate success. We've had credit take up move from around 7% of new starters to 14% of new starters. That is not enough to arrest the decline, and we'll -- it should slow it down a little bit, but it was not enough to arrest the decline in the customer base, and it's certainly not enough to grow it.
And I think the thing that we have to realize as a business is that if the credit business is to grow, and we're not sure that it can, but if it is to grow, then it needs to fundamentally change and recognize that it isn't competing with old mail order-style accounts or even store cards. It's really got to compete with credit cards. And we started that process 6 months ago. As we said in our presentation in March, we reduced our minimum payments from 9.4%, which was unusually high, to 5%, which is at the top end of the credit card minimum payments. Credit card minimum payments tend to be between 2% and 5%. This, obviously, gives the customer greater flexibility and a sense of security as well that they're not going to -- they don't need to worry as much about their Directory account if, in any 1 month, they don't have so much money.
We have been really surprised by the effect that this has had because it hasn't just affected the customers who pay the minimum payment; it's affected virtually the whole base. And if you look at what happened to our balances, we introduced the change in February, and this is what happened to our credit balances since then. Around GBP 120 million of additional debt, and that is -- you'll remember, I said GBP 135 million additional debt earlier on, the GBP 15 million is driven by sales. This is driven by the change.
We think that, that will be around GBP 200 million by the end of the year. Now we won't panic for this. We thought it'd be between GBP 30 million and GBP 40 million. And obviously, the upside of this is that it gives us potentially an enormous increase in interest income.
And we've been debating -- we've debated what to do with that. And obviously -- the obvious thing to do is to take it straight to profit. We think the right thing to do, both in terms of treating our customers fairly and in terms of making sure that the business stands a chance of growing in the long term, is to give the lion's share of that back to our customers through an APR reduction, so we intend to reduce the APR from 24.99% to 22.9%. It's still at a high rate, but it puts us in the credit card range. And remember, that it was 25.99% 18 months ago.
Just to sort of give you a feel of where that sits in competitive terms. Home shopping, these are 5 major home shopping -- the 5 major home shopping account companies. Their interest rates range from around 30% to 41%. The one with the bar in between, they've got 2 rates, a high-risk rate and a low risk rate. Store card rates are running from between 20% to 30%. Again, 20% is only for low-risk customers. Credit card market running between somewhere 26% and 16%, 26% for high-risk customers, 16% for low-risk customers. Where that leaves our account, not super competitive for credit cards, but not completely out of the ballpark. And we think that, that gives it a chance of being competitive going forward.
In addition, when I come on to talk about the profitability, you'll see that there is a potential that we may have underestimated the profit from the additional GBP 200 million of debt. If we have, we intend to reinvest that at some point, probably in the middle of next year, in further interest rate reductions. Probably, we will look to differentiate between high-risk and low-risk customers, so that we'll be competitive at the low risk end. We think actually at the high risk end, we already are quite competitive at 22.9%. But we're looking at -- to be more competitive at the low risk end. So that's sort of the plan for business. But that does -- that is contingent on us making the profit on that.
In terms of profitability, just looking at the full year profit, GBP 200 million of debt, additional interest income at the previous rate of interest would have given us GBP 50 million of income. Bad debt provision at 6.5%. That is higher than we are currently experiencing on the whole base. And the reason we've taken that view is because we don't yet know what the effect of the minimum payments will be on bad debt. It may be that giving people longer to pay actually degrades the value -- degrades the quality of the debt, so we've been quite conservative about that.
Cost of funding, around -- we seeing the 4% cost of funding around the cost of our bonds, gives us a gross gain of GBP 29 million. An APR reduction of 2% will cost us GBP 19 million. It leaves the net profit of GBP 10 million, which is 5% on the GBP 200 million that we've invested. And in terms of return on capital, adding back the cost of funding, return on capital at 9%, which, not coincidentally, is 1% ahead of the rate in which -- of which we're prepared to buy back our shares. In terms of the effect in this year, we expect the net profit to be around -- the net profit effect to be around GBP 1 million in the current year.
Moving on to retail wages. Obviously, this has been a subject of much discussion, comments. And I thought that this is -- there are 2 sections here. First of all, to talk about what NEXT has done with its wages, because I think we're slightly ahead of the curve, and the second is to talk about the effect of the living wage premium.
In terms of what we've done, this is a history of the national minimum wage. And this is what's -- what we've done with our starter rates. We started this journey about 2.5 years ago because we wanted to improve the quality of service that we had in the stores, and we recognized that in order to do that, we were going to have to increase our pay rates and change some of our terms and conditions.
So this is what's happened to pay rates. Pay rates have by -- in October, when the national minimum wage goes to GBP 6.70, our wage would go to GBP 7.04. That is before an average of 50p per hour bonus that we pay in customer service bonuses. So there is another -- in reality, there's another 50p to add to that.
In terms of increase on 2012, that's a 13% pay increase. As important, if not more important, we have changed the way we recruit and contract our staff. In the past, we've gone for very large numbers on small contracts in the belief that, that gives us flexibility, and it does to a certain extent give you flexibility. The problem is a lot of people working on low-hour contracts means that you have people who aren't particularly experienced, training is a big percentage of that total cost and they're less loyal to the business.
The other thing is that it doesn't give you the flexibility that at first, it might appear to, because the -- if you give someone a very low contract at hours per week, they're more likely to take on another job, which means they actually become less flexible. So we've moved significantly as through natural turnover, as people have left the business rather than recruit people to replace them, we have reallocated their hours across the staff base.
And as a result of that -- sorry, I should say before that, you're wondering how is that funded, the 13% pay rise? Payroll as a percentage of sales in 2012 was 11.9%. You would expect, given a 13% increase in starter rates, that to go up to at least 12.5%, it's up to 12.8%. In fact, it's actually gone up by 0.2%. So the majority of this has been funded through productivity improvements, some of which I've bored you with in the past. There's no one big idea that that spans this [ph] lots and lots of small initiatives to improve productivity.
But coming back to hours. What we've done is increase hours by 26%, which means on average, the average member of staff is only 43% more with NEXT than they were 4 years ago. We think that gives us more experienced, better trained, better motivated and more loyal staff.
In terms of the living wage premium. It's taken us some time to get our heads around this. The Chancellor said 2 things: first of all, he said the living wage premium will be reaching 60% of the median earnings by 2020; and the other is that it was set to reach GBP 9 by 2020. And the first thing to understand is that those 2 things are not necessarily the same thing, in that it makes an assumption about what will happen to inflation in median wages between now and 2020.
And what we've done is separate out the effect of the -- taking the living wage premium of 60% to the effect of inflation on general wages and the median itself. So in terms of analyzing that, national minimum wage, that's not our rate, the national minimum wage of GBP 6.70, that goes to GBP 7.20 next year. That will cost us around GBP 2 million in 2016.
In terms of taking that to the median, assuming no inflation in wages, that will go to GBP 7.85. So that would take it to GBP 7.85, and it's the assumed assumption which the OBR forecast to be around 4.5%. And if you want to read -- a fascinating read on this, try appendix B of the OBR's financial outlook -- July financial outlook document. It really is actually very interesting and worth reading, but that is the inflation that takes you from GBP 7.85 to GBP 9.35.
So there are 2 elements to this. There's a legislative element, which gets that GBP 7.85. An inflation element that takes it forecast to GBP 9.35. In order to get it to GBP 9, wage inflation would need to be 3.5% per annum in the median.
In terms of assessing the cost, the likely costs to NEXT, given the scenario set out by the OBR, this is how we've analyzed it. We take our staff wages of 2016 at GBP 7.20. That's 55% of the median. We then looked that the other levels of management in the business. And what you can see is that, I had to go from supervisor to junior manager, floor manager, store manager. As we progressed through the wage hierarchy, we are getting a sort of 9% to 10% wage differential at each level.
If that -- if the staff level goes to GBP 7.85, you can see there's only a 2p difference with the next manager up. What we've assumed for the purposes of our modeling is that we can compress the current 9%, 10% differential to around 7%. So this is assuming a 7% differential, which we think at these rates of pay should be enough to encourage people to take promotion.
That means the first level manager has to go up 6.7%, next one at 4.6%, 2.7% and at 0.5% manager. At around GBP 10.50, there's no further knock-on effect. In terms of the cost of that, the cost is around GBP 11 million. That includes our estimate of any subcontracted costs, where subcontractors are paying the -- are not yet paid the living wage premium.
The knock-on effect is surprisingly high at GBP 16 million. Most of that doesn't come from these managers. We would have to -- you all look at that and think we've got far too many managers if that were the case. The knock-on effect comes from the fact that more skilled jobs within the business, more skilled or more demanding jobs which are less attractive, currently have a 9%, 10% premium to our store wages, things like call center operatives. And we've assumed that those wages, that if a call center operative was on the same level as a junior supervisor, that their wages would have to rise by as much to attract them to that job rather than doing a shop drop. So that's why the knock-on effect is much higher than you might initially expect. Cost of that is GBP 27 million. So a lot of money, but in the scheme of things, it's not transformative.
If you then add on 4.5% inflation, it doesn't make any difference to the cost of the living wage premium. The orange and the green blocks remain exactly the same. But obviously, that 4.5% is a big cost because if you translate that across our wage bill, which is around GBP 600 million across the group, that adds another GBP 120 million of cost. So you're at GBP 147 million of additional cost to the group in 2020 if wage inflation comes through as expected.
What you can see from that is that the living wage premium is a relatively small part of the total increase. In terms of the price rises required to pay for that, we estimate the price rise would need to be in the order of 6%. So -- of which 1% comes from the living wage premium.
Incidentally, in case you're thinking, we would always choose to pass it through as price rather than take the cost hit, because if you take a cost hit of 104 [ph] -- if you do the math, the maths are overwhelming in favor of price rise. Because you say, take GBP 147 million as a percentage of our profits, that's around 18%. If you work out what sales would have to fall by to give us the same drop in profit, you're at a level that could not possibly be caused by a 6% price increase. So we were -- in the past, when we increased our prices by around 7% about 3, 4 years ago, when we had a big devaluation in the pound, and that adversely affected sales by about 1.5%.
So what you can see is that, given the choice, take the hit or pass it on, the maths are overwhelming in favor of passing on the cost, particularly if wages have risen by 4.5% per annum, because that 6% price increase needs to be taken in the context of a country where, on average, people are earning 19% and more.
So actually, in the OBR scenario, the effect of the living wage premium at GBP 27 million is not -- it's not welcome, but it's not unmanageable. The problem potentially comes if wage inflation falls below the 3.5% and the 60% median target is dropped and the GBP 9 target is maintained. Because once you start moving the living wage premium much above 60%, it begins to have 2 impacts, and it's worth just explaining back to our chart here. That increases wages by 2% compound to 2020. Our staff will then be paid GBP 7.79 and getting them to GBP 9 would be a 15.6% increase, and what you can see is rather than being paid 2p less than the first manager, they're actually paid 50p more. So the increase required here is far greater and so on and so forth until you get to manager 4.
But what you then realize is actually, hold on a second, this is now affecting manager 5 because manager 4 is at GBP 11.97 and manager 5, through inflation, will only get to GBP 11.93. So you have to begin to cascade the effects of the median wage further up the wage hierarchy.
And there are 2 problems on this: one is that the cost of implementing this, obviously, increased dramatically. So from GBP 27 million, we estimate this would cost nearer GBP 70 million, and we think that is probably conservative.
The other problem, which is more serious for the wider economy, is that at that point, the median wage will be GBP 14. So you end up with a situation where raising the living wage to GBP 9 begins to move the median. And then you end up with a situation that all of you will be hugely familiar with, with your circular references in your spreadsheets, which you tend to just fudge. I know that we all do that. But you end up with this potential inflationary loop, where the living wage premium begins to move the target against which it's set.
So in summary on this, if wage inflation comes through as expected, or even if it comes through anywhere at or around 3.5%, we're not worried. If it comes through at less than 3.5%, we're still not worried if the target remains 60%. The only worry would be if the target remains GBP 9 and inflation comes through at significantly less than 3.5%. In that situation, costs escalate and price rises would be less easy to swallow. Wages would still be rising faster than prices, but those price rises become harder to swallow, which would have an adverse impact on sales, which means that the impact on profit would be significant. Is that -- now I've said it, it all sounds completely simple. But I think that's where we are on the living wage premium.
In terms of profit guidance. Full Price sales for the full year, 3.5% to 6%. We haven't -- we only gave this forecast in July. I haven't seen anything in trade that would suggest we should change that. Second half, we're expecting to be between 3.5% and 7.5%. That might sound ambitious with 5.5% at the midpoint. It's significantly better than the first half, but remember that the first half was 16% up on 2 years.
If you look at the second half on 2 years, it's only at 10%. And at that point, everyone in the room moves from thinking, these guys are wild optimists to actually -- they are being too conservative on their sales estimates for the second half. We think this number is right. 2 years ago, it was a bad summer and a good Christmas. If you look at these numbers against 3 years ago, both come out exactly at 19%. So we think that these numbers are realistic. 
Full year -- full price sales, we're forecasting to be up GBP 160 million. And just we wanted to update you as to how we expect -- where we expect that growth to come from the first -- from the estimates we gave in the first half, lower than we originally forecast a drop in like-for-like sales, roughly same amount from New space. 
NEXT online, biggest winner in our forecast from GBP 10 million to GBP 50 million. LABEL around GBP 30 million, that's GBP 10 million less than we were expecting, but still a 20% increase in full price sales. Overseas, GBP 40 million, which is pretty much in line with our initial estimates.
In terms of where that leaves profit. Profit growth, we think, will be somewhere between 2.9% and 8%. Layer on top of that ordinary dividend yield of 2.2%, special dividend yield of 3.3% and that's based on GBP 72.33, which was the share price at the beginning of the year, gives total shareholder return of growth in earnings plus dividend somewhere between 8.4% and 13.5%, which, in the context of a very difficult first half, we think is respectable.
And on that note, I'm going to finish. I think that is, for me, a record in terms of speed.

In terms of increase on 2012, that's a 13% pay increase. As important, if not more important, we have changed the way we recruit and contract our staff. In the past, we've gone for very large numbers on small contracts in the belief that, that gives us flexibility, and it does to a certain extent give you flexibility. The problem is a lot of people working on low-hour contracts means that you have people who aren't particularly experienced, training is a big percentage of that total cost and they're less loyal to the business.
The other thing is that it doesn't give you the flexibility that at first, it might appear to, because the -- if you give someone a very low contract at hours per week, they're more likely to take on another job, which means they actually become less flexible. So we've moved significantly as through natural turnover, as people have left the business rather than recruit people to replace them, we have reallocated their hours across the staff base.
And as a result of that -- sorry, I should say before that, you're wondering how is that funded, the 13% pay rise? Payroll as a percentage of sales in 2012 was 11.9%. You would expect, given a 13% increase in starter rates, that to go up to at least 12.5%, it's up to 12.8%. In fact, it's actually gone up by 0.2%. So the majority of this has been funded through productivity improvements, some of which I've bored you with in the past. There's no one big idea that that spans this [ph] lots and lots of small initiatives to improve productivity.
But coming back to hours. What we've done is increase hours by 26%, which means on average, the average member of staff is only 43% more with NEXT than they were 4 years ago. We think that gives us more experienced, better trained, better motivated and more loyal staff.
In terms of the living wage premium. It's taken us some time to get our heads around this. The Chancellor said 2 things: first of all, he said the living wage premium will be reaching 60% of the median earnings by 2020; and the other is that it was set to reach GBP 9 by 2020. And the first thing to understand is that those 2 things are not necessarily the same thing, in that it makes an assumption about what will happen to inflation in median wages between now and 2020.
And what we've done is separate out the effect of the -- taking the living wage premium of 60% to the effect of inflation on general wages and the median itself. So in terms of analyzing that, national minimum wage, that's not our rate, the national minimum wage of GBP 6.70, that goes to GBP 7.20 next year. That will cost us around GBP 2 million in 2016.
In terms of taking that to the median, assuming no inflation in wages, that will go to GBP 7.85. So that would take it to GBP 7.85, and it's the assumed assumption which the OBR forecast to be around 4.5%. And if you want to read -- a fascinating read on this, try appendix B of the OBR's financial outlook -- July financial outlook document. It really is actually very interesting and worth reading, but that is the inflation that takes you from GBP 7.85 to GBP 9.35.
So there are 2 elements to this. There's a legislative element, which gets that GBP 7.85. An inflation element that takes it forecast to GBP 9.35. In order to get it to GBP 9, wage inflation would need to be 3.5% per annum in the median.
In terms of assessing the cost, the likely costs to NEXT, given the scenario set out by the OBR, this is how we've analyzed it. We take our staff wages of 2016 at GBP 7.20. That's 55% of the median. We then looked that the other levels of management in the business. And what you can see is that, I had to go from supervisor to junior manager, floor manager, store manager. As we progressed through the wage hierarchy, we are getting a sort of 9% to 10% wage differential at each level.
If that -- if the staff level goes to GBP 7.85, you can see there's only a 2p difference with the next manager up. What we've assumed for the purposes of our modeling is that we can compress the current 9%, 10% differential to around 7%. So this is assuming a 7% differential, which we think at these rates of pay should be enough to encourage people to take promotion.
That means the first level manager has to go up 6.7%, next one at 4.6%, 2.7% and at 0.5% manager. At around GBP 10.50, there's no further knock-on effect. In terms of the cost of that, the cost is around GBP 11 million. That includes our estimate of any subcontracted costs, where subcontractors are paying the -- are not yet paid the living wage premium.
The knock-on effect is surprisingly high at GBP 16 million. Most of that doesn't come from these managers. We would have to -- you all look at that and think we've got far too many managers if that were the case. The knock-on effect comes from the fact that more skilled jobs within the business, more skilled or more demanding jobs which are less attractive, currently have a 9%, 10% premium to our store wages, things like call center operatives. And we've assumed that those wages, that if a call center operative was on the same level as a junior supervisor, that their wages would have to rise by as much to attract them to that job rather than doing a shop drop. So that's why the knock-on effect is much higher than you might initially expect. Cost of that is GBP 27 million. So a lot of money, but in the scheme of things, it's not transformative.
If you then add on 4.5% inflation, it doesn't make any difference to the cost of the living wage premium. The orange and the green blocks remain exactly the same. But obviously, that 4.5% is a big cost because if you translate that across our wage bill, which is around GBP 600 million across the group, that adds another GBP 120 million of cost. So you're at GBP 147 million of additional cost to the group in 2020 if wage inflation comes through as expected.
What you can see from that is that the living wage premium is a relatively small part of the total increase. In terms of the price rises required to pay for that, we estimate the price rise would need to be in the order of 6%. So -- of which 1% comes from the living wage premium.
Incidentally, in case you're thinking, we would always choose to pass it through as price rather than take the cost hit, because if you take a cost hit of 104 [ph] -- if you do the math, the maths are overwhelming in favor of price rise. Because you say, take GBP 147 million as a percentage of our profits, that's around 18%. If you work out what sales would have to fall by to give us the same drop in profit, you're at a level that could not possibly be caused by a 6% price increase. So we were -- in the past, when we increased our prices by around 7% about 3, 4 years ago, when we had a big devaluation in the pound, and that adversely affected sales by about 1.5%.
So what you can see is that, given the choice, take the hit or pass it on, the maths are overwhelming in favor of passing on the cost, particularly if wages have risen by 4.5% per annum, because that 6% price increase needs to be taken in the context of a country where, on average, people are earning 19% and more.
So actually, in the OBR scenario, the effect of the living wage premium at GBP 27 million is not -- it's not welcome, but it's not unmanageable. The problem potentially comes if wage inflation falls below the 3.5% and the 60% median target is dropped and the GBP 9 target is maintained. Because once you start moving the living wage premium much above 60%, it begins to have 2 impacts, and it's worth just explaining back to our chart here. That increases wages by 2% compound to 2020. Our staff will then be paid GBP 7.79 and getting them to GBP 9 would be a 15.6% increase, and what you can see is rather than being paid 2p less than the first manager, they're actually paid 50p more. So the increase required here is far greater and so on and so forth until you get to manager 4.
But what you then realize is actually, hold on a second, this is now affecting manager 5 because manager 4 is at GBP 11.97 and manager 5, through inflation, will only get to GBP 11.93. So you have to begin to cascade the effects of the median wage further up the wage hierarchy.
And there are 2 problems on this: one is that the cost of implementing this, obviously, increased dramatically. So from GBP 27 million, we estimate this would cost nearer GBP 70 million, and we think that is probably conservative.
The other problem, which is more serious for the wider economy, is that at that point, the median wage will be GBP 14. So you end up with a situation where raising the living wage to GBP 9 begins to move the median. And then you end up with a situation that all of you will be hugely familiar with, with your circular references in your spreadsheets, which you tend to just fudge. I know that we all do that. But you end up with this potential inflationary loop, where the living wage premium begins to move the target against which it's set.
So in summary on this, if wage inflation comes through as expected, or even if it comes through anywhere at or around 3.5%, we're not worried. If it comes through at less than 3.5%, we're still not worried if the target remains 60%. The only worry would be if the target remains GBP 9 and inflation comes through at significantly less than 3.5%. In that situation, costs escalate and price rises would be less easy to swallow. Wages would still be rising faster than prices, but those price rises become harder to swallow, which would have an adverse impact on sales, which means that the impact on profit would be significant. Is that -- now I've said it, it all sounds completely simple. But I think that's where we are on the living wage premium.
In terms of profit guidance. Full Price sales for the full year, 3.5% to 6%. We haven't -- we only gave this forecast in July. I haven't seen anything in trade that would suggest we should change that. Second half, we're expecting to be between 3.5% and 7.5%. That might sound ambitious with 5.5% at the midpoint. It's significantly better than the first half, but remember that the first half was 16% up on 2 years.
If you look at the second half on 2 years, it's only at 10%. And at that point, everyone in the room moves from thinking, these guys are wild optimists to actually -- they are being too conservative on their sales estimates for the second half. We think this number is right. 2 years ago, it was a bad summer and a good Christmas. If you look at these numbers against 3 years ago, both come out exactly at 19%. So we think that these numbers are realistic. 
Full year -- full price sales, we're forecasting to be up GBP 160 million. And just we wanted to update you as to how we expect -- where we expect that growth to come from the first -- from the estimates we gave in the first half, lower than we originally forecast a drop in like-for-like sales, roughly same amount from New space. 
NEXT online, biggest winner in our forecast from GBP 10 million to GBP 50 million. LABEL around GBP 30 million, that's GBP 10 million less than we were expecting, but still a 20% increase in full price sales. Overseas, GBP 40 million, which is pretty much in line with our initial estimates.
In terms of where that leaves profit. Profit growth, we think, will be somewhere between 2.9% and 8%. Layer on top of that ordinary dividend yield of 2.2%, special dividend yield of 3.3% and that's based on GBP 72.33, which was the share price at the beginning of the year, gives total shareholder return of growth in earnings plus dividend somewhere between 8.4% and 13.5%, which, in the context of a very difficult first half, we think is respectable.
And on that note, I'm going to finish. I think that is, for me, a record in terms of speed.

5687431.eventHeadline: H & M Hennes & Mauritz AB (publ), Nine Months 2015 Earnings Call, Sep 24, 2015
5687431.transcript_text1:
Welcome to this telephone conference on the occasion of H&M's 9-month results 2015. With me is our CFO, Jyrki Tervonen, and we'll be happy to answer your questions after the presentation. You'll find the presentation slides to this telephone conference on hm.com.
H&M continued to perform well in the first 9 months of 2015, both in terms the sales and profits. Our collections were well received for all group brands. We continued our successful expansion with stores and online, and we kept taking market share. As our offering is reaching more and more customers every day, we're also developing and improving our ranges in order to make our offering even better. This summer, for example, we launched our new concept H&M Beauty, and it has got off to a very good start. We also continue investing long term in areas such as IT and online to further strengthen the H&M Group and secure future expansion.
Please turn to the slide Sales. In the first 9 months of the year, sales including VAT reached SEK 153 million, an increase of 12% in local currencies and 21% in SEK, which is a good proof that our collections are well appreciated worldwide. In the third quarter, sales increased by 11% in local currencies. Translating to SEK, sales including VAT amounted to SEK 53.4 billion, an increase of 18% compared to last year. Sales were strong in June and July. But in August, sales were negatively affected by the unseasonably warm weather in many of our large European markets. We also met a strong comparable with growth of 19% in August 2014. Looking at the month of September, the weather has become more normal. And in the period of the first -- the 22nd September, sales increased by 12% in local currencies compared to the same period last year. 
And now to look at results, please turn to the next slide. Gross profit in the third quarter was SEK 25.7 billion. That corresponds to a gross margin of 55.9% compared to 58.3% last year. The combined effect on the purchasing costs from the external factors remained negative. This is mainly due to the strengthening of the U.S. dollar. Markdowns in relation to sales increased by 30 basis points compared to the third quarter last year mostly due to the increased price activities in August. For the 9-month period, gross profit amounted to SEK 75.2 billion with a gross margin of 56.9%.
Please turn to the slide SG&A. Cost control in the group remains good. In the third quarter, selling and administration costs increased by 20% in SEK to SEK 18.8 billion. In local currencies, the increase was 12%. The increase in SG&A is mainly related to the expansion and the long-term investments.
To look at profits, please turn to the next slide. Profits developed well in the first 9 months of the year. Although in the third quarter, profits were negatively affected by the transaction effect on the strong U.S. dollar on purchasing costs. Higher costs for our long-term investments also impacted profits negatively, as did the weak August sales and the subsequent rise in markdowns due to the unseasonably warm weather. In the third quarter, profit after financial items was at the same level as last year at SEK 6.9 billion. And in the 9-month period, profit after financial items increased by 11% to SEK 20 billion. 
Please turn to the table sales and profit. With an estimated tax rate of 23.5%, tax amounted to SEK 1.6 billion in the third quarter. Net profit thus was SEK 5.3 billion, equaling earnings per share of SEK 3.21, largely unchanged from the third quarter last year. In the 9-month period, net profit increased by 12% to SEK 15.4 billion. This equals an EPS of SEK 9.29, up from SEK 8.31 last year.
And now for some other key data, please turn to the next slide. Stock-in-trade on the 31st August amounted to SEK 25.2 billion, an increase of 40% in SEK. In local currencies, the increase was 38%. While the reported increase in the stock-in-trade is high, both the composition and the level of the stock-in-trade are considered good with higher proportion of new garments compared to the same time last year. The increase in stock-in-trade is explained mainly by the value increase caused by the strengthening of the U.S. dollar and also by the store and online expansion. Also, a large part of the increase in stock-in-trade, more precisely SEK 1.2 billion, is due to a bookkeeping effect arising from our previously communicated change in the process around invoice management for sourcing.
Cash flow from current operations was SEK 17.8 billion compared to SEK 18 billion. And investments in terms of CapEx totaled SEK 7.9 billion for the first 9 months of the year compared with SEK 6.4 billion in the same period last year. Investments covered mainly new stores, but also IT and logistics. For 2015 as a whole, CapEx is still expected to reach approximately 11 point -- to SEK 11.5 billion based on exchange rates from the 30th of November 2014. The financial position of the H&M Group remains strong. Liquid funds were SEK 11 billion compared to SEK 13.5 billion. Return on equity was 44.7% compared to 46.1%.
And now for some comments on expansion, please look at the slide, Store Expansion. H&M's strong expansion continues. The plan for 2015 remains intact, meaning approximately 400 new stores net. The largest expansion is taking place in existing markets, with China and the U.S. being the largest expansion markets. We added 164 new stores net in the first 9 months of the year, bringing the total numbers of stores to 3,675 stores at the end of the third quarter. This means that we will open around 240 new stores net in the fourth quarter alone.
We're adding 5 new H&M markets this year. Taiwan, Peru and Macau have already opened, and all have had a very good start. In October, we will open the first H&M stores in India and South Africa. The first store in India will open in the Select Citywalk mall in New Delhi. And in South Africa, the first store will open in Cape Town in the V&A Waterfront. Today, we also announced 3 new H&M markets for next year: New Zealand, Cyprus and Puerto Rico.
And now some words on our other group brands, please turn to the next slide. Expansion continues for COS, & Other Stories, Monki, Weekday and Cheap Monday. In 2015, expansion focuses mostly on & Other Stories and COS. COS will add 4 new markets this year. Bahrain opened their franchise in February, Luxembourg, Hungary and Canada are planning to open this autumn. COS will open in the Czech Republic in 2016.
Please turn to the next slide. In parallel to our rapid store expansion, we're also adding e-commerce in a growing number of markets. H&M's online store, hm.com is opening in 10 new markets in 2015. Eight of them had opened already, it's Portugal, Poland, the Czech Republic, Romania, Croatia, Hungary, Bulgaria and Belgium, and customer reception has been great in all of these markets. With the addition of Switzerland and Russia this autumn, H&M will be available online in 23 markets by the end of this financial year. In 2016, the plan is to offer e-commerce in a further 9 existing H&M markets. These markets are Ireland, Japan, Greece, Croatia, Slovenia, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania and Luxembourg. 
We also continue to broaden the H&M product range. Please turn to the slide H&M Beauty. In July, we began the launch of our new concept, H&M Beauty, which is now available in 700 stores across 28 markets and online. Following a very good start, we will continue to roll out H&M Beauty to more stores. Already by the end of November, H&M Beauty will be available in the total of approximately 900 stores in 42 markets and online. We're also developing other new concepts and brands, which we will communicate more on at a later date.
And now before we move on to the Q&A session, just some words on current development. We have an exciting fashion season ahead of us. And like we said initially, sales in the first 2 weeks of September were up 12%. Meanwhile, if we look at market conditions regarding sourcing as the U.S. dollar strengthens further during the sourcing period to the fourth quarter, purchasing costs for the fourth quarter have been even more negatively affected than the purchasing cost for the third quarter. As always, we're continuously reviewing our customer offering in each market, and we are monitoring the market closely to ensure that we offer the best combination of fashion, quality, price and sustainability.
And now we're happy to take your questions. [Operator Instructions] Thank you.

5687431.transcript_text3:
I've got 2 questions. The first one is about current trading. Are there any calendar effects in the final week of September that we need to take account of, please?

---

No, there is no major calendar impact in September.

---

A couple of questions. Firstly, what was your average selling price at the beginning of September '15 versus the beginning of September '14, please? And my second question is, given sort of the slight weakness in the renminbi and a bit of time on your side, have you managed to mitigate some of these further pressures in the fourth quarter sort of COGS outlook?

---

Again Rebecca, I'd like to remind you, please one question at a time. It's easier for everyone. But I do remember your first question was regarding ASP. And unfortunately, we do not -- for competitive reasons, we do not comment the ASP. Sorry.

---

And what's next, the second question?

---

Just with the -- with a bit of time on your side, have you managed to mitigate any of these U.S. dollar-related pressures in the COGS as we go into the fourth quarter and into the first half of 2016?

---

Of course, when we're looking at the U.S. dollar effect for the purchases we have done for Q4, as Nils previously said, it's even a more negative effect for those purchases. And we are always looking to different ways of mitigating negative FX. But exactly how we are working with our pricing, et cetera, that we will always keep to ourselves for competitive reasons. But always, as we have said, we are always looking into finding efficiencies and changing sourcing market, et cetera.

---

I do have 3 questions, but they are very short. One at a time.  So the first one on Russia. Given I've seen some significant growth there, I wonder what is the composition between price and volume, have you raised prices in Russia?

---

Russia, we're very happy with Russia. And as we say, we do very well, and we continue to expand. We're also very happy to launch e-commerce already this autumn. And regarding pricing effects, we don't want to give too much details because what happened last year, especially was that the ruble depreciated quite substantially towards most other currencies. And I would say every retailer had to compensate and increase prices. And we have also adjusted, but we say less probably than the rest of the market and thus increased our competitive advantage even further.

---

Okay, very helpful. And then on China, on a more negative note there. If we try to decompose some sort of like-for-like, these have been negative. But understandably, you do grow stores quite rapidly there. Given that you do operate online, does it come maybe to a surprise of the existing store base is not as productive maybe? Or this is in line with your budget in the past about China?

---

We continue to expand very rapid in China. We're very happy with the development and also the profitability. And we launched e-commerce as late as last year, last autumn. And then, of course, from quarter-to-quarter, there'll always be volatilities. So no concern really for the numbers in China. I would say, the contrary, we look -- there's a huge potential. We'll continue to expand very rapidly this autumn, this quarter. So we really are optimistic for the future going on in China.

---

Of course, in Q3, if you compare to Q2, yes, the local growth is less than in Q2 for sure. But we are still on a good level when it comes to the turnover and the profitability. So we are, as Nils said, continuing our rapid expansion in the Chinese market.

---

Okay. And last one on the 4Q store openings. So in 4Q, you're going to open close -- store number in order to hit your 400, which is close to the number that you opened the entire 2011. And we'd -- so it is the highest in a quarter historically by quite some amount. Are there any concerns that you have that -- should we be thinking that maybe the locations are being compromised or it just happens to be timing issue from Q3 to Q4 and it's been as usual? What I'm trying to get to -- sorry, and that is a longer-than-I-thought question. ---

And so they are, as you said, business as usual. Yes, it's a huge amount of stores that we're going to open, but we have fantastic teams in the countries. Thank you, operator, and good day, everyone. Thanks for joining us for Sasol's year-end results conference call. Joining me on this call from Sasol, as you heard, is our CFO, Bongani Nqwababa. As you would have seen after yesterday's media presentation, we announced another resilient group-wide performance, notwithstanding the steep decline in crude oil prices for the period under review. 
Our 2015 financial results are a testament to the ongoing commitment of our people and the decisions we took to strategically reposition Sasol for the future and the agility with which we respond to a fundamentally different energy landscape.

I'll begin by reminding you of how the decisions we have taken as a management team are providing Sasol with a solid platform during these challenging times in our industry. We'll then go into more detail on our strong operational financial performance in FY '15 with Bongani providing a complete overview of our full year results. Before wrapping up, I'll take you through certain refinements to our strategic agenda including the advancements we've been making on our dual regional strategy and the momentum we are maintaining on selective growth projects in Southern Africa and the U.S. And to conclude the call, we'll recap how Sasol is protecting shareholder value by proactively prioritizing our business activities.

And you could see from the graph, up until 2014, the Brent oil price was stable, between $95 and $125 per barrel, and the Sasol share price gained traction reaching a ZAR 500 to ZAR 600 range. Certainly up until September of last year, group-wide, we were sitting in a reasonably comfortable position. However, at the time, we reiterated that we could not allow our achievements to lull us into a false sense of security. 
To assure organizational stability and resilience during both the good and bad times back in November 2011, and as highlighted by the first colored blocks on the slide, we launched an internal change program driven by the group executive committee. In terms of this top-down program, we refined our corporate strategy and priorities, streamlined our management structures and adapted our values and culture. And having done significant ground work internally, in November 2012, we commissioned an independent diagnostic study to better understand and respond to the root causes of the mounting cost creep, primarily here in South Africa. And we were determined to arrest the concerning trend where our group cash fixed costs from 2007 to 2012 were increasing at a compound rate of 11% annually. 
Moving to the second colored block from the graph, we then formally launched our Business Performance Enhancement Programme in 2013, which focused on simplicity, efficiency and cost optimization across the group. Our diagnostics revealed that our cost and complexity challenges primarily related to how we organize ourselves along the siloed, somewhat bureaucratic product-based operating model. Although our Sasol operating platform had evolved over a decade, we had never undergone a clean slate design review and thus never really changed. A crucial milestone of our Business Performance Enhancement Programme was the implementation of our completely revamped operating model on July 1, 2014. That's the third colored block on the slide. In restructuring, rightsizing and repositioning the company, not only were we reducing our cost base and simplifying our systems and processes, we significantly improved our ability to proactively respond to an ever-changing environment. At the time, of course, as we all know, Sasol was in a great position having closed off FY '14 with another set of outstanding results. And as you see here, our share price was at all-time highs. So as you've heard before, we were definitely fixing the roof while the sun was shining. 
However, with a sudden change in market forces, the energy landscape was shaken up. Coupled with strong oil production from the U.S. and Russia, the determining factor in November 2014 was OPEC's decision to protect market share by maintaining and actually surpassing their output quota levels. Given the significance of the OPEC decision on the global energy sector, and only days later in early December, the Sasol management team started formulating a compressive plan to conserve cash in response to the anticipated lower-for-longer oil price environment. As you may recall, our Response Plan caters for a cash conservation target range of ZAR 30 billion to ZAR 50 billion over a 30-month period from January 2015 to end June 2017. Now to Slide 6 and looking at the management interventions in greater detail and our key achievements in FY '15. Under the Business Performance Enhancement Programme, our new operating model has been in place for 15 months now and it is definitely delivering results. We have completed the company-wide organizational redesign with the last of the streamlined structure changes and simplified reporting lines to be implemented by October 2015. B4TP9G2.transcript_text1:
Okay. Thank you, operator, and good morning, everyone. Today, we reported our financial results for the second quarter of fiscal 2016. I will briefly go over sales and store growth highlights for the second quarter before turning it over to Michael who will provide you with more detailed update on our financial results and key operating initiatives.
The results being reported this quarter reflect the exceptional performance of our business as all key financial and operating metrics were met or exceeded. This performance is a direct consequence of our attention to details, rigorous cost controls and the successful execution of our merchandising strategy. In this quarter, our sales increased by 14.1% as a result of strong organic sales growth, driven by high comparable store sales. Sales were also driven by the continued expansion of our store network. In this quarter, we achieved a 7.9% increase in same-store sales through an increase in the average basket size and an increase in the number of transactions. We continue to attract new and existing customers to our broad assortment of merchandise offered at exceptional value. Sales growth is consistent across all regions of the country, which testifies to the consistent shopping experience in all our stores. 
During the quarter, we opened 17 net new stores compared to 18 net new stores opened in Q2 last year. Our total store count across Canada is now 989 stores compared to 917 stores as at August 3, 2014. We can expect to hit a new milestone soon as we reach 1,000 stores in the upcoming quarter. So far this year, we have opened 34 net new stores and we still expect to open 70 to 80 net new stores in fiscal 2016. 
EBITDA grew 35.3% this quarter, which is attributable to strong sales and margins, general and administrative costs that benefited from the scaling impact of our sales and continued focus on operational efficiencies. On the purchasing side, before you ask the question, I can tell you that we have not been adversely impacted by the recent developments reported in the news about China and its economy. It's business as usual on that front. From a merchandising point of view, summer sales were very strong as customers and consumers responded well to our line of gardening and summer products. The careful execution of our merchandising strategy and the implementation of operational improvements have made us stronger as we grow. We continue to reach new customers in an efficient manner, all the while providing a consistent shopping experience in all our stores. 
With that, I will turn this call over to Michael.

---

Thank you, Larry, and good morning, everyone. So during the second quarter, we increased our sales by 14.1% to $653.3 million from $572.6 million in the prior year. The increase in sale was fueled by the opening of 72 net new stores over the past 12 months and a same-store sales increase of 7.9% during the quarter. The same-store sales growth consisted of a 6.2% increase in basket size, which reflect the consumer demand for higher price point items and a 1.5% increase in the number of transactions driven by higher traffic in our stores. 
In this quarter, 76% of our sales originated from products priced higher than $1 compared to 67% in the corresponding quarter last year. Debit card penetration also increased as 46% of sales were paid with credit -- debit cards, sorry, compared to 43% in the corresponding period of the previous fiscal year.
In the second quarter, our gross margin was 38.4% of sales compared to 36% of sales in Q2 last year. Our higher-than-expected gross margin this quarter was driven by the positive scaling impact of the stronger-than-anticipated same-store sales growth and the higher product margins in anticipation of an increase in the average forward exchange contract rate. In other words, we made select changes to our product offering and price mix while we are still hedged at favorable rates in anticipation of the next year's currency headwind when those hedges roll out. The increased gross margin is also attributable to lower logistics and transportation costs as a percentage of sales, as a result of operational improvements as well as reductions in rates and fuel surcharges. 
As a result of these factors, we've revised our fiscal 2016 gross margin target range from 36% to 37% to 37% to 38% for the full year. However, beyond fiscal 2016, the gross margin should fall back within the 36% to 37% range as we factor in the headwinds related to the weakening Canadian dollar. As we have stated in the past, we actively manage our gross margin by continually reinvesting in the value proposition offered to consumers and by refreshing up to 30% of our product offering on a yearly basis. In the longer term, the goal remains to target a margin that will sustain reasonable profitability while ensuring that our customers are getting the value proposition expected to stimulate continued sales growth. 
Our Q2 G&A as a percentage of sale was 15.9% compared to 17.1% last year. This progression is a result of continued improvements in labor productivity achieved through initiatives implemented at the store level as well as the positive scaling effect of higher sales on fixed costs. Overall, we still expect an improvement in the G&A margin for the full fiscal 2016 year compared to fiscal 2015 as we continue to target a margin between 16.5% and 17% for fiscal 2016. 
With higher sales and margins and lower G&A costs, our EBITDA in Q2 grew 35.3% to $150 -- to $146.9 million or 22.5% of sales. Q2 net earnings increased to $95.5 million or $0.74 per diluted share compared to $68.9 million or $0.51 per diluted share in the second quarter of fiscal 2015. 
Cash flows from operations increased to $124.8 million in Q2 from $106.9 million in the corresponding quarter of the previous fiscal year. This increase is due to the higher earnings during the current quarter. We spent $21.5 million on capital expenditures in Q2 compared to $17.1 million last year. These expenditures relate primarily to the new store openings as well as investments in information technology. In fiscal 2016, we still expect to incur capital expenditures in the range of $95 million to $100 million depending on the number of new stores that we open. 
On June 10, 2015, we announced the renewal of our normal course issuer bid. The 2015-2016 NCIB program will allow us to purchase for cancellation up to 3.5% of issued and outstanding shares at June 9, 2015, or up to 4.5 million shares over the 12-month period from June 17, 2015, to June 16, 2016. 
In Q2 F '16, we repurchased for cancellation under the 2014 and '15 NCIB program and under the 2015 and 2016 NCIB program, a total of 1,531,154 shares at an average cost of $72.82 per share, for a total cash consideration of $111.5 million. From an operational perspective, we have made significant investments in stores over the past few years to continuously improve our operational efficiencies, and we are seeing the results in our G&A margin that has steadily improved over the years. Investments in advanced labor scheduling tool have provided better control of our labor time and attendance and the allocation of labor hours at the stores, which has positively contributed to the productivity increases we've seen. Also, the continuous improvement of replenishment models have -- has allowed better in-stock inventory positions, and we believe this has a positive impact on sales. These investments are part of the initiatives that provide ongoing benefits to our operations. Additional productivity investment in fiscal 2016 include the rollout of WiFi that has just been successfully completed. In terms of hardware rollout, all of these initiatives have laid down the foundations for mobile technology that is currently being piloted. These initiatives are intended to reduce nonvalue-added tasks at the store level, optimize inventory levels in the store and reduce wait times at the cash registers. We expect to start seeing the benefits of these new operational efficiencies by the end of next year in fiscal 2017. 
Overall, we are very pleased with the financial and operating performance of the company this quarter and the continued progress being made on our key initiatives. 
So this ends our formal remarks and we can now take questions. So operator, I'll turn the call over to you.

Yes. I guess the point is if you can throw up robust numbers at $1.30, you potentially have an opportunity at $1.15.

Right.

---

In other words, it's not an automatic gross margin benefit. You adjust to competition.

I think we -- at the higher price points, we hope we can give the same value that we give at every other price point. And we're going to make sure we do that. I can only say that much for that question. I think at $3.50 and $4, we'll be able to give value, the same values as we gave in every other single -- every other price point. ---

Got you. Okay. I just want to get a sense of what the variance is between your worst-performing stores versus the company average.

No, we don't go into that detail, Chris. But essentially, as we said in the past, they all contribute and it's pretty much all well bunched up.

---

Yes. I've never looked at it that way, Chris. And I can only say that we've never ever closed a store because of performance. The only reason we close stores is because either a better location becomes available or the shopping center is redoing itself and wants us out for a period of time and then wants us back in when they finish their renovations.
