【質問: Perry Caicco (Analysts)】
You said that in anticipation of the changing FX rates, you made some changes to your merchandising programs. Can you tell us exactly the kinds of changes that you made?

---

【回答: Michael Ross (Executives)】
Well, not exactly. That would take too long. But in the process of that, Perry, is that, as you know, we hedge out anywhere between 6 months to a year so that the buyers, when they commit, know at what currency they are committing to. But knowing that the currency continues to increase and that eventually, your hedge cost, if the currencies stabilize, finishes by reaching the level of the currency that we see today, the spot rate. So in anticipation of that, you don't want to modify your prices every 6 months, so you set the price point and the return in considering that future cost that's going to be a factor in determining the return. So that's basically it.

---

【質問: Perry Caicco (Analysts)】
And did you make these changes before the quarter or during the quarter?

---

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
During the quarter.

---

【回答: Michael Ross (Executives)】
No. Well it's done before. The commitments are made before. You receive the goods afterwards and when you start receiving and you start selling them. But because you paid them at a hedged rate, which is lower than the spot that's coming up or the hedge rate that we will have in the future, you already have that activity going on.

---

【質問: Perry Caicco (Analysts)】
And do you expect to do more of this in the next couple of months?

---

【回答: Michael Ross (Executives)】
Yes. As you all know, we have that visibility and that's how we look at it.

---

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
But it will come to an end.

---

【回答: Michael Ross (Executives)】
But it comes to an end. I mean, it's a timing. Because of the sharp increase -- you haven't seen that in the past because you didn't have any sharp increase. So it just melted in. Whereas now, you had a sharp increase in the currency. And so you forecast that and you take it into account when you determine the mix and the return on your products.

---

【質問: Perry Caicco (Analysts)】
Okay. And on a slightly different topic, the 6.2% increase in transaction size, was that mostly higher-priced items in the basket? Or were there more items in the basket?

---

【回答: Michael Ross (Executives)】

---

【質問: Perry Caicco (Analysts)】

---

【回答: Michael Ross (Executives)】
We're -- I mean, the biggest impact was last year with the Ontario increase. Now it's lower, so we're not -- we don't have major concerns as to the -- any major increase. Well, this year, we know it, and next year, we don't anticipate major increase.

---

【質問: Irene Nattel (Analysts)】
Sorry to continue to beat this horse, but I just want to make sure that I'm understanding what you're saying. So you don't want to keep raising or adjusting your price points. So let's just say there's a certain gardening tool that you have the benefit of buying with the currency hedged at a higher price. You introduced it this summer at $2, but you know that looking out, it would have to be at $2.20 or $2.50 in order to protect your margins. So you just introduce it at $2.50 so that it will be the same price. Is that kind of what we're talking about here?

---

【回答: Michael Ross (Executives)】
It's -- I mean, yes, it's not necessarily a markup. It's -- we refresh 25% to 30% of the items. So it could be new items coming in. And where you say exactly, the logic is there. I mean, you're right. So you know that the cost of the currency is going to go up 3 months later because you hedge out, but the spreads get tighter and tighter or higher and higher as you move out. So you know that, eventually, you're going to catch up to the 1 25 or whatever level it is. But it's higher than the hedged rate. So in anticipation of that, obviously, you take that into account and you factor it into your price point and the item that you're presenting.

---

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
Yes. Let me give -- get another -- give you another crack at that question. Let's say at one point, the spot was 1 25 and you're hedged at 1 08, well, the buyers are looking at, certainly I am, are looking more at the 1 25 than the 1 08. So we're costing at -- whether it's a new item or an old item. We're costing at that 1 25. We're -- so our retail prices indicate that margin of costing, yet our spot is at 1 08 or 1 10 or at 1 12. So that difference is creating that difference in the margins.

---

【質問: Irene Nattel (Analysts)】
That's very helpful, Larry. So just continuing on with the subject of FX. On the last call, you said that at this point in time, there are no plans to introduce higher price points but that if the dollar continues to weaken, that could be something that you would look at in future. Could you update us on your current thinking?

---

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
Now Irene, who said that? Okay, I did. You're right, you're right. Okay. So basically, we'll do nothing, like I said, for FY '16, nor would we do anything for Q1 and Q2. Now for Q3 and Q4, I think we'll get a better indication from our trip to the Orient in October. And the new price points, if indeed we decide to go that way, would be $3.50 and $4. But we will at all times maintain, and that's important to note, a maximum price point on foodstuffs at $2. So foodstuffs will continue as they have to maintain the $2 price point. I don't think we may get the occasional discount for that devaluation of the renminbi, but not always because they've hedged out and they claim that they can't give us that 2%. Well, we're certainly not going to be able to solve the Canadian dollar versus the American dollar decrease or the weakening of the Canadian dollar. So we -- to absorb 25% to 35% is almost impossible. So go ahead, Irene.

【質問: Irene Nattel (Analysts)】
I was going to say that's extremely helpful, Larry.

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
Okay. Anything else?

Yes, that's the case.

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】

Michael, you have raised your in-year gross margin guidance higher, but I noticed you're maintaining your line of the 16.5% to 17% on G&A. Yes. The reason is, as we get into Q3, Q4, we're against bigger same-store sales. Last year, Q3 was 5.9 and Q4, 8.5, in terms of scaling. 【質問: Kenric Tyghe (Analysts)】
Fair enough. And just one other quick question. Just in terms of the competitive intensity and specifically Western Canada, have you noticed any change with perhaps a competitor of yours being -- competitor or 2 of yours being a little distracted or otherwise? 【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
Well, I -- out west, they're certainly -- if you're talking about Dollar Tree, they certainly are there. I'm not counting the number of stores they're opening or closing. There is more competition out west with Dollar Tree being there. They have about 200 stores and they're all from Ontario West. But our numbers show that across the country they're about the same. So...

---

【回答: Michael Ross (Executives)】
Yes. I think you're right, Larry.

---

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
I don't know what to add besides that.

---

【回答: Michael Ross (Executives)】
There is no -- I mean, the -- if we look at -- what we do is from coast-to-coast in every province or region, we have reports on how the stores do compared to the chain and compared to the previous years. 【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
But Kenric, if I were Dollar Tree and I just took over 8,000 stores in the states, I would be distracted, I can say that. I would be, but maybe they're not, but I would be. It's quite a challenge.

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
Yes. So Michael, I think it's a combination of both. You said it. It's a combination of where you can change packaging. I mean, if you have a food container, it's one food container. 【回答: Michael Ross (Executives)】

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】

【質問: James Durran (Analysts)】
And new DC in Western Canada is still several years off if you continue to squeeze more productivity out of the existing facility?

I think it happens by default. When you're out buying today, and we're not talking 20 years ago, we're talking today, you're being offered less and less items that could sell for $1 to $1.25. 【質問: Peter Sklar (Analysts)】

Steady as she goes.

---

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
Yes. We're happy with the progress.

【質問: Derek Dley (Analysts)】
Yes. Okay. Understood. And just regionally, were any areas stronger in terms of same-store sales this quarter or traffic?

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
Yes.

---

【回答: Michael Ross (Executives)】
Yes. Well, yes. That sort of basket we don't disclose. And so traffic is, again, coast-to-coast and it's pretty stable. And yes, there's not much more we can say about that.

---

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
We're happy. We're happy. We seem to be getting our share.

【質問: David Hartley (Analysts)】
Fair enough. That's great. And store sizes, are you still planning to look at similar-sized stores on average as you continue to roll through 70, 80 stores per year?

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
Well, haven't you heard that we've taken over 30 Target stores?

【質問: David Hartley (Analysts)】
No.

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】

【質問: David Hartley (Analysts)】

【質問: Vishal Shreedhar (Analysts)】

Yes.

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】

【質問: Keith Howlett (Analysts)】

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
We don't sleep very well with all this information, I'll tell you.

【質問: Keith Howlett (Analysts)】

Huntsville.

---

Right. And just finally, how does the back-to-school merchandise assortment look? And if you have any comments on the results there.

Neil, do you have anything to say on back-to-school in July, Neil?

---

【回答: Neil Rossy (Executives)】
No. It was in line with last year. We were happy with the results.

It would be in addition to.

---

【質問: Brian Morrison (Analysts)】

---

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】

In the past, we've given better value when the Canadian dollar was improving versus the U.S. dollar. We tended to give it. But to speculate what will happen if it became $1.15 and it's not $1.30 any longer, I don't know. Things happening in China. Where will China be? Where will oil, where will fuel be? To speculate that far out, I just don't -- I wouldn't like to do that.

---

【回答: Michael Ross (Executives)】
But again, Brian, we'll be all on the same level playing field as others. So I mean, it's always -- you're always comparing and managing it relative to others too.

---

【質問: Brian Morrison (Analysts)】
Yes. I guess the point is if you can throw up robust numbers at $1.30, you potentially have an opportunity at $1.15.

---

【回答: Michael Ross (Executives)】
Right.

---

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
You can conclude that. I would conclude that, if I were you. But I don't know how -- what things will be like when that happens and if that happens. And hopefully, that happens because it's a lot easier to manage $1.15 than $1.30 or $1.35.

---

【回答: Michael Ross (Executives)】
In other words, it's not an automatic gross margin benefit. You adjust to competition.

---

Just as you contemplate introducing new higher price points, will most of the additional SKUs be used to expand your -- the assortment of the existing categories? Or do you see it as an opportunity to perhaps get into new categories that you're presently not providing?

---

【質問: Chris Li (Analysts)】
Okay. And I think it sounds like as you contemplate higher price points, it would suggest that your confidence in your ability to preserve the value proposition for the consumer at the higher price point will still be preserved. 【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
I think we -- at the higher price points, we hope we can give the same value that we give at every other price point. And we're going to make sure we do that. I can only say that much for that question. I think at $3.50 and $4, we'll be able to give value, the same values as we gave in every other single -- every other price point. And again, we're competing on the same playing field as everybody else in Canada. So that should be the case.

---

【質問: Chris Li (Analysts)】
Got you. Okay. 【回答: Michael Ross (Executives)】
No, we don't go into that detail, Chris. But essentially, as we said in the past, they all contribute and it's pretty much all well bunched up.

---

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
Yes. I've never looked at it that way, Chris. And I can only say that we've never ever closed a store because of performance. The only reason we close stores is because either a better location becomes available or the shopping center is redoing itself and wants us out for a period of time and then wants us back in when they finish their renovations. But we've never closed a store. But to answer your question directly, I've never looked at it that way, showing me my -- the worst-performing. And -- so I can't answer your question legitimately. Thank you.

BP9DL90.transcript_text1:
Thank you. Good morning to all the participants in this webcast conference call regarding Inditex results for interim half-year 2015. I am Pablo Isla, and here with me today are Ignacio Fernández, our CFO; and Marcos López, Capital Markets Director. 
The results for the first half of 2015 shows that Inditex continues its global growth. We enjoy our global sales platform that fully integrates the stores and online, and offers huge growth opportunities. Inditex operating performance in the period has been strong. Sales have increased 17%. Like-for-like sales growth came in at 7%. Our operations have also shown high efficiency and tight operating control over the period. 
Let me also tell you that in terms of expansion, our space growth and online launches for the year are on track. We have opened stores in 35 different markets over the period, demonstrating the global reach of Inditex business model. We continue to see significant growth opportunities for Inditex globally.
We are in a unique position as we enjoy a global sales platform that fully integrates the stores and online as the best way to respond to the demands of our customers. This is a result of our highly differentiated business model, with a central inventory position, distribution to all our stores globally at least twice a week and orders received by our customers between 2 and 48 hours. This works perfectly in conjunction with our global online sales presence. We have a strong operation to continue expanding profitably in the coming years.
In terms of growth, we have maintained a strong expansion. We achieved positive like-for-like sales growth in all geographical areas in the first half of 2015. We have a global presence, and we have further diversified our operations over the period. 
Let me now hand over to Ignacio who will provide you with some detail behind the headline numbers, and I will join you later for the outlook section.

---

Thank you. Inditex has had strong operating performance in the half-year 2015. All the lines of the profit and loss account show significant growth. We have achieved net sales of EUR 9.4 billion, EBITDA of EUR 2 billion and net income of EUR 1.2 billion.
Starting with sales, I would like to tell you that Inditex performance had been very satisfactory. Net sales have grown 17%. Like-for-like sales grew 7%. The store and online launches for the year are on track.
Should currencies remain at current levels, we [indiscernible] positive translation on sales for fiscal 2015. 
Breaking down sales, let me highlight that like-for-like sales growth was very strong at 7% in the first half of 2015, on a top of 4.5% for the same period last year. New sales space contributed 7% to total sales. 
The translation of sales in currency is different to the euro has contributed to reported sales growth of 2.5 percentage points due to the higher exchange rates versus our reporting currency. 
Gross profit has increased 17% to EUR 5.5 billion, resulting in 58.1% gross margin on sales. We have sustained our commercial policies over the period.
Operating expenses are tightly under control. They have grown 15%, reflecting mainly  growth in the space, and include all the start-up costs for new openings. Operating working capital remains negative as a result of the business model. The working capital evolution is in line with the performance of the business. 
I will now hand over to Marcos, who will elaborate on the performance of Inditex concepts.

---

In terms of space addition and online launches, we are on track. Continuing with our global expansion, we have opened stores in 35 markets over the period. Global online launches have continued at a very rapid pace. 
Regarding the performance by concept in 2015, Zara continues to represent approximately 2/3 of group sales; the younger concepts, around 1/3. 
I would like to highlight the strong operating performance of the group over 2015. Let me point out that in this period, all group Inditex's concepts have achieved a strong positive like-for-like sales growth. The younger concepts grouped together have grown satisfactorily. Let me highlight that Bershka, Stradivarius and Zara Home have performed very strongly. 
I will now hand over to Pablo for the outlook section.

---

For the remainder of 2015, we will continue to invest in the expansion of our business across a number of markets, all of which offer attractive long-term returns to our store and online platform. 
Inditex is present on 5 continents and in all the key markets, demonstrating the group's global reach. We manage a diversified sales platform in 88 markets. The current base offers huge growth potential for the coming years.
Inditex enjoys a fully integrated, globally scalable online operation which fits perfectly with its business model. This has allowed a rapid growth of our online presence in conjunction with our retail expansion. We will continue rolling out online sales in selected markets to enhance our global presence.
In retail, Zara launched online sales in Taiwan on September 2, and Hong Kong and Macau on September 9. 
With respect to expansion in 2015, let me highlight that the space growth and online launches are on track. Ordinary capital expenditure for 2015 will be around EUR 1.35 billion. 
For the coming years, we'll continue to see a strong growth opportunities, with capital expenditure growing below the space growth. 
Regarding the outlook for the second half of 2015, I would like to add that the store and online sales in local currencies from the 1st of August to the 10th of September have grown by 16%. 
Just as a reminder, we will make our final 2014 dividend payment of EUR 0.26 per share on the 3rd of November.
And this is all from us. We will be pleased to answer any questions you may have.

Just one question then on the gross margin. I wonder what your expectations are for the full year now, given the slightly stronger performance in the first half and also a very strong start to Zumiez full price sales in Q3.

---

Well, thank you very much. First of all, what I would say is that we are very satisfied with the evolution of the gross margin in the first half of the year. And as you know and we always say that gross margin needs a combination of many different factors: fashion trends, product mix, like-for-like, markups, markdowns, product management, the comparables, so there many things involved in the gross margin. I think something which is very relevant talking about Inditex is that our model is highly flexible, and it provides a strong stability to the gross margin. This is why we always talk about the stable gross margins, knowing that, for us, stable means plus/minus 50 basis points. So what I can tell you about the gross margin for the full year is very similar to what we were saying in June in the first quarter results publication, that we are expecting a stable gross margin for the full year, knowing that, for us, stable means plus/minus 50 basis points. And that this year, the growth of gross margin will be probably a bit higher in the first half and a bit lower in the second half, given the evolution of the U.S. dollar/euro exchange rate. But I think what is very relevant is that, globally, a stable gross margin for the full year.

---

Okay. I mean, for Inditex, I guess the second half is more important than the first half. So should we assume that the full year might be towards the lower end of a stable, given the dollar/euro effect coming through in the second half? Or will that be offset by the stronger full price sales trend?

---

You know that the gross margin, as I was saying at the beginning, is a combination of many different things. So you look up your mathematics. That is why when we talk about stable, we always say plus/minus 50 basis points. And this is what we expected for this year, a stable gross margin for the full year, understanding that, for us, stable means plus/minus 50 basis points. So as I was telling you before, you know that, for us, we have 2/3 of our sales first in euro-denominated, 1/3 in dollar-denominated. So given the evolution of the U.S. dollar/euro exchange rate, the gross margin would be a bit higher in the first half and a bit lower in the second half. But as I was saying to you before, normally, we are expecting a stable gross margin for the full year. And of course, as you were saying in your question, we can say that we are satisfied with the start of the season, very strong start of the season in all the different geographies, in all the different concepts. But as we always say, we're only talking about the first 6 weeks of the season, and we have the full season in front of us. But what we can say is that we have had a positive start of the season.

---

Were there any special impacts or explanations for the strength of sales in the 1st of August to 10th of September period, please? And in particular, were there increased markdowns during that period?

---

No, no, nothing to do with the final part of your question, nothing at all to do with that. You have seen that we have increased the gross margin in the first half of the year, so nothing to do with that. No, we have had a very -- I think I was saying to you before, it's a strong start of the season in all the different geographies, in all the different brands. So this is what we can say. It's a combination of everything. Of course, everything is based on the flexibility of our business model, and many of our collections have been quite well received by our customers, so a strong start of the season. It's a combination of everything, this full integrated approach between the stores and online, so that is what we can say. You know that we always say that we prefer not to extrapolate in a short period of time for the full season, but this is what is behind that. Of course, as always, our like-for-like sales growth is volume-driven. This is always the case, and it continues being the case.

---

Just my question is on online. Given it's clearly quite a big growth driver, can you give us a sense of now where it is as a percentage of sales and how much of your like-for-like growth is coming from the online sales? And are you seeing any cannibalization in your stores where you've launched online geographically?

---

Well, when you say the strong like-for-like sales growth, it's difficult to talk about cannibalization from any point of view. If you think about the first half, we have achieved 7% like-for-like sales growth; and  in first half 2014, it was 4.5%. So it's 7% on top of 4.5%, so it's difficult to talk about cannibalization. What we can tell you is that, for us, what is very, very relevant is this fully integrated approach. This approach, considering stores and online, you know that from the very beginning, we have believed very much in this fully integrated approach, the possibility of having a store delivery, seeing a store replenish, ordering online from the stores. For our customers, well this is the case. And for us, it's very important. Online sales, that is also very important. The number of visits to that area remains growing to our own different online pages and apps with the different brands. So with this fully integrated approach. The same customers see the products [ph] online, sometimes they buy online, sometimes they go to the stores. Once they decide to buy online that they order, they ask for the in-store delivery or they go to the stores and they buy in the stores. So with this fully integrated approach is what is very relevant for us. We have millions of people visiting our online apps and web pages every day, so this is what we think is very strong. I'm answering specifically your question, we have not seen any type of cannibalization in the stores.

---

And will you be willing to give us your percentage of annualized sales now as a percentage from online? Can you give us that number?

---

No, because we see this as a fully integrated approach between stores and online, so that is why we prefer not to specify which part comes from where.

---

And can you just quickly explain why there is such a contraction in receivables and perhaps give us what constant-currency inventory growth was, given that there's quite a significant sort of negative growth in capital base at the end of the first half?

---

Yes, Rebecca, it's a very technical question, but  recent change in the VAT regulation that allows to net the payments to a capital contribution [indiscernible] have nothing to do with us. Earlier  you're talking about the inventory, as you can see, inventory is very tightly knit as well. You see that the working capital is working according to our business model, negative working capital, and the lines are working very much in line with the business.

---

Like I said it's not just the timing issue that should carry through to the full year, should it?

---

Well, they  say, it's a minor issue. You see that the mechanics of the working capital remain very much in line with evolution of the business.
